goals.question: What is the correlation between GDP per capita and life expectancy?
goals.visualization: Scatter plot of GDP per capita vs. life expectancy
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand if there is a positive correlation between GDP per capita and life expectancy. If there is a strong correlation, it could suggest that countries with higher GDP per capita tend to have better healthcare systems and higher life expectancies.

goals.question: What is the distribution of CO2 emissions per capita across different regions?
goals.visualization: Box plot of CO2 emissions per capita by region
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the range and distribution of CO2 emissions per capita across different regions. It could help us identify regions that have higher or lower emissions and potentially inform policy decisions related to reducing emissions.

goals.question: What is the trend in population growth over time?
goals.visualization: Line chart of population growth over time
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand if the population is growing or declining over time. It could also help us identify any significant changes in population growth rates and potentially inform policy decisions related to population management.

goals.question: What is the distribution of child mortality rates across different regions?
goals.visualization: Histogram of child mortality rates by region
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the range and distribution of child mortality rates across different regions. It could help us identify regions that have higher or lower child mortality rates and potentially inform policy decisions related to improving child health.

goals.question: What is the relationship between education and fertility rate?
goals.visualization: Scatter plot of fertility rate vs. mean years of schooling
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand if there is a negative correlation between education and fertility rate. If there is a strong negative correlation, it could suggest that increasing access to education could help reduce fertility rates and potentially inform policy decisions related to family planning.

code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import matplotlib.ticker as ticker
import pandas as pd

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    plt.figure(figsize=(6, 6))
    plt.scatter(data['GDP per capita'], data['life expectancy'])
    plt.xlabel('GDP per capita')
    plt.ylabel('Life Expectancy')
    
    if len(plt.xticks()[0]) > 20:
        plt.gca().xaxis.set_major_locator(ticker.MaxNLocator(20))
    
    plt.title('What is the correlation between GDP per capita and life expectancy?', wrap=True)
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)
chart.show()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import matplotlib.ticker as ticker

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    plt.figure(figsize=(6, 6))
    data['date'] = pd.to_datetime(data['date'], errors='ignore')
    box_plot_data = data.groupby('region')['CO2_emissions_per_capita'].apply(list)
    plt.boxplot(box_plot_data.values, labels=box_plot_data.index)
    plt.xticks(rotation=45)
    plt.gca().xaxis.set_major_locator(ticker.MaxNLocator(20))
    plt.title("What is the distribution of CO2 emissions per capita across different regions?", wrap=True)
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)
chart.show()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import matplotlib.ticker as ticker

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    plt.figure(figsize=(6, 6))
    
    data['date'] = pd.to_datetime(data['date'], errors='ignore')
    data = data.sort_values(by='date')
    
    plt.plot(data['date'], data['population_growth'])
    
    if len(plt.xticks()[0]) > 20:
        plt.gca().xaxis.set_major_locator(ticker.MaxNLocator(20))
    
    plt.xticks(rotation=45)
    plt.title("What is the trend in population growth over time?", wrap=True)
    
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)
chart.show()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import matplotlib.ticker as ticker

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    plt.figure(figsize=(6, 6))
    data['child_mortality'] = pd.to_numeric(data['child_mortality'], errors='ignore')
    data['region'] = data['region'].astype('category')
    data.groupby('region')['child_mortality'].plot(kind='hist', alpha=0.5, legend=True)
    plt.xlabel('Child Mortality Rates')
    plt.ylabel('Frequency')
    plt.title('What is the distribution of child mortality rates across different regions?', wrap=True)
    if len(plt.xticks()[0]) > 20:
        plt.gca().xaxis.set_major_locator(ticker.MaxNLocator(20))
    plt.xticks(rotation=45)
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)
chart.show()

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import matplotlib.ticker as ticker
import pandas as pd

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    plt.figure(figsize=(6, 6))
    plt.scatter(data['mean_years_of_schooling'], data['fertility_rate'])
    plt.xlabel('Mean Years of Schooling')
    plt.ylabel('Fertility Rate')
    
    if len(plt.xticks()[0]) > 20:
        plt.gca().xaxis.set_major_locator(ticker.MaxNLocator(20))
    
    plt.title('What is the relationship between education and fertility rate?', wrap=True)
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)
chart.show()
